snippet: Though he drives a cab in Chicago six days a week to make ends meet, the exiled writer Osama Alomar has hopes of becoming a distinct American literary voice, as well as a Syrian one.
abstract: Syrian writer Osama Alomar, who has been living in exile in Chicago since 2008, still tries to write while working as taxi driver; Fullblood Arabian, Alomar's first book to be translated into English, is set to be published by New Directions; Alomar will take a break from his grueling routine to attend PEN World Voices literary festival in New York.
lead_paragraph: Though he drives a cab in Chicago six days a week to make ends meet, the exiled writer Osama Alomar has hopes of becoming a distinct American literary voice, as well as a Syrian one.

headline.seo: Osama Alomar Pursues His Literary Ambitions in Exile
headline.main: Taking Fares, and Writing in Between
